author: JENNIFER EDER
title: Blenheim man allowed to make his own way to prison
text:
Blenheim man allowed to make his own way to prison JENNIFER EDER Last updated 18:03, February 8 2017 FAIRFAX NZ 
A judge has allowed a man to make his own way to Christchurch Men's Prison instead of being transported in a prison van. 
A Blenheim man caught trying to sell cannabis and methamphetamine will get one last road trip before his prison term starts. 
Jason Adam Beckford, 48, has been allowed to make his own way to prison after concerns the long journey in a prison van would be too taxing. 
His lawyer Rob Harrison said at his sentencing on Wednesday Beckford had hip problems and the trip from Blenheim to Christchurch would be difficult for him. 
The drive was longer than usual after the November earthquake blocked State Highway 1 and the prison van travelled through Greymouth, Harrison said. 
Judge David Ruth said he would allow one of Beckford's friends to drive him to Christchurch Men's Prison, giving him until noon on Friday to arrive. 
Police said Beckford offered to sell small amounts of methamphetamine in Christchurch and Blenheim between April and May 2015. 
He was charged with nine counts of offering to supply methamphetamine. 
He was also charged with cultivating cannabis, possessing cannabis, possessing a bong and offering to supply cannabis. 
Beckford admitted the cannabis charges but denied the methamphetamine charges, electing a jury trial. 
He was found guilty after a four-day jury trial in December. 
Harrison said at his sentencing at the Blenheim District Court there should be a distinction made between offering to sell drugs and actually selling them. 
There was no evidence of how many transactions actually went ahead, he said. 
A pre-sentencing report said Beckford was not a methamphetamine user and did not associate with people who used it. 
However he did know people in "the scene" and used this to sell small amounts, he said. 
Beckford admitted to being a heavy cannabis smoker and smoked it every day, using about an ounce a week. 
"Because of his heavy use, he has had to sell some to maintain his own habit," Harrison said. 
Judge Ruth accepted that Beckford was motivated to sell drugs by his own addiction. 
He was sentenced to two years and four months' imprisonment. - The Marlborough Express
